review.title: Dynamic Mechanism Design for Markets with Strategic Resources
review.abstract: The assignment of tasks to multiple resources becomes an interesting game theoretic problem, when both the task owner and the resources are strategic. In the classical, nonstrategic setting, where the states of the tasks and resources are observable by the controller, this problem is that of finding an optimal policy for a Markov decision process (MDP). When the states are held by strategic agents, the problem of an efficient task allocation extends beyond that of solving an MDP and becomes that of designing a mechanism. Motivated by this fact, we propose a general mechanism which decides on an allocation rule for the tasks and resources and a payment rule to incentivize agents' participation and truthful reports. In contrast to related dynamic strategic control problems studied in recent literature, the problem studied here has interdependent values: the benefit of an allocation to the task owner is not simply a function of the characteristics of the task itself and the allocation, but also of the state of the resources. We introduce a dynamic extension of Mezzetti's two phase mechanism for interdependent valuations. In this changed setting, the proposed dynamic mechanism is efficient, within period ex-post incentive compatible, and within period ex-post individually rational.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We look at the example of an organization that has multiple sales and production teams. Sales teams receive project contracts that are executed by the production teams. The problem that both teams have is that they outsource the projects (tasks) to the production teams (resources). The efficiency of the production teams and the workload of the projects is monitored by the management. This problem is reduced to the individual teams that have been well studied in the literature (Bertsekas, 2005). We name the efficiency levels and workloads together as states of tasks and resources. States are usually observed by the individual teams.

sections.text: The problem of dynamic task allocation to strategic resources, discussed in the last section, falls into the broader context of a market with interdependent values. The values of task holders (buyers) are not negative, while those of resources (sellers) are not positive (essentially it is costs), which constitute the environment of an exchange economy. We follow the definitions of the last section and modify slightly certain notation to address this more general attitude of dynamic mechanism design. Let's allocate at the time t, given the types of payments reported. Although the allocation policy is given by π, we will show that the allocation decision can be reduced to per-day decisions, which are due to the Markov nature of type development. Once the agents are assigned, their values match Vi perfectly (in the field of play).

sections.heading: 4 The Generalized Dynamic Pivot Mechanism
sections.text: Before introducing the proposed mechanism, let's look at other possible approaches to solving the problem by discussing an attempt to determine the allocation and payment itself. Fixed payment mechanism: A candidate for the above hiring is to select a group of agents and send them fixed payments. Allocation can be made on the basis of the agent's performance history, but it is immediately apparent that this fixed payment mechanism would not be truthful. Since the payment is fixed after selecting an agent, the agents would report a type that would maximize their chance of being selected. Since the allocation is based on the history of performance that is commonly known, agents with better history would take advantage of the system by reporting their type incorrectly. The above mentioned candidate mechanism suggests that in order to achieve an efficient allocation in a dynamic environment, one must consider the expected future development of the types of agents, which would be reflected in the allocation and payment decisions. Moreover, we do not have an interdependent set of values in our two.

sections.heading: 4.1 Stage A: Type Reporting Stage
sections.text: In turn t, each agent observes its true type θi, t, i, N. Agents are asked to indicate their types and report θ-i, t, i-N, which may differ from their true types due to the strategic nature of the agents. At the end of this stage, the allotment decision is made, at least in turn A.

sections.heading: 4.2 Stage B: Value Reporting Stage
sections.text: We assume that this observation is perfect for the agents. At this stage, the agents are asked to report their observed values. They report V-i, t, i-i-N. At this stage, we would also assume that if the agents cannot strictly win by false reporting, they report their true observed values. At the end of this step, payment is made to the agent i, i-N. Immediately after the proof of the main result, we discuss why the standard dynamic panning mechanism does not ensure that IC can do this, while a two-step dynamic panning mechanism can.

sections.heading: 5 Simulation Results
sections.text: In this section we will show the characteristics satisfied by GDPM through simple illustrative experiments and compare the results with an average efficiency (BB). In addition to the already proven characteristics of GDPM, we will also examine two other characteristics here. We will call a payment consistency mechanism (PC) if the buyer pays and seller receives payments in each round, and the budget is balanced (BB) if the sum of money transfers to all agents is not positive (no deficit). For brevity, we will choose a relatively small example, but analyze it in detail. Experimental Setup: Let us analyze the example of Section 1, where we will consider three agents: one project coordinator (task holder / buyer) and two production teams (seller). Let us assume that the difficulty of the task and the efficiency of each team can assume three possible values: high (H), medium (M) and low (L), which are private information.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have formulated the problem of dynamic resource allocation as a dynamic mechanism-design problem and analysed its characteristics. • We have proposed a dynamic mechanism that is efficient, truthful and individually rational in a dependency-driven exchange economy. • The mechanism has similar calculation costs to its non-strategic counterpart. • We have illustrated and examined the characteristics of our mechanism through simulations and found that the proposed mechanism simultaneously does not satisfy EFF, EPIC, EPIR, PC and BB. An accurate characterisation of the (in) possibilities for the model we are examining would be more desirable. Other directions for future work would be to design mechanisms with additional desirable characteristics in this environment. If the impossibility is correct, then the limits of payment inconsistency and budgetary imbalance must be examined.

If the efficiency levels of the production teams and the workloads of the projects are observable by the management (controller), this problem reduces to an MDP, which has been well studied in the literature (Bertsekas, 1995; Puterman, 2005). Let us call the efficiency levels and workloads together as states of the tasks and resources. However, the states are usually observed privately by the individual teams (agents), who are rational and intelligent. They, therefore, might strategically misreport to the controller to increase their net returns. Hence, the problem changes from a completely or partially observable MDP into a dynamic game among the agents. We will consider cases where the solution of the problem involves monetary transfer. Hence, the task owners pay the resources to execute their tasks. A socially efficient mechanism would demand truthfulness and voluntary participation of the agents in this setting. The reporting strategy of the agents and the decision problem of the controller is dynamic since the state of the system is varying with time. In addition, the above problem has two characteristics, namely, interdependent values : the task execution generates values to the task owners that depend on the efficiencies of the assigned resources, and exchange economy: a trade environment where both buyers (task owners) and sellers (resources) are present. An exchange economy is also referred to as a market. The above properties have been investigated separately in literature on dynamic mechanism design. Even though these mechanisms work for an exchange economy, they have the underlying assumption of private values, i.e., the reward experienced by an agent is a function of the allocation and her own private observations. Mezzetti (2004, 2007), on the other hand, explored the other facet, namely, interdependent values, but in a static setting, and proposed a truthful mechanism. In this paper, we propose a dynamic mechanism which combines the flavors of interdependent values with exchange economy that applies to the strategic resource assignment problem. It extends the results of Mezzetti (2004) to a dynamic setting, and serves as an efficient, truthful mechanism, where agents receive non-negative payoffs by participating in it.
